content:

## üé• **Nouveaut√©s pour les cr√©ateurs**

### üõ†Ô∏è **Mises √† jour de Studio**

### üé¨ **Nouveaut√©s pour Shorts**

title: Lincoln Center‚Äôs Collider Fellows explore how tech could transform the performing arts
content:
### R√©sum√©
Le Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts lance sa deuxi√®me promotion de Collider Fellows, un programme accueillant des artistes multidisciplinaires explorant l'impact des technologies √©mergentes sur les arts vivants. Les six nouveaux fellows travaillent avec des technologies comme la r√©alit√© virtuelle, l'intelligence artificielle et le syst√®me 4DSound. Le programme offre un espace de travail, une bourse financi√®re et un soutien pour une dur√©e de neuf mois, sans obligation de projet final.

---

### üé≠ **Lincoln Center lance sa deuxi√®me promotion de Collider Fellows**

√Ä une √©poque marqu√©e par l'anxi√©t√© face √† l'impact de la technologie sur les arts et la culture, le **Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts** se concentre sur les **nouvelles opportunit√©s** avec son programme **Collider Fellowship**. Ce programme accueille des artistes multidisciplinaires pour explorer comment les technologies √©mergentes peuvent transformer les **performances live** et les arts vivants.

Aujourd'hui, le c√©l√®bre centre des arts de New York annonce sa **deuxi√®me promotion de Collider Fellows** ‚Äî un groupe de six artistes travaillant dans des domaines allant de la **r√©alit√© virtuelle** √† l'**intelligence artificielle**, en passant par le **syst√®me immersif 4DSound**.

#### üí° **Une vision optimiste de la technologie dans les arts**
Jordana Leigh, vice-pr√©sidente de la programmation au Lincoln Center, a d√©clar√© : *"J'aime qu'ils soient tous des personnes vraiment r√©fl√©chies qui ne pensent pas seulement √† l'≈ìuvre elle-m√™me, mais √† la mani√®re dont elle s'inscrit dans une conversation plus large sur les arts et la technologie."*

Leigh, une *"optimiste √©ternelle"* quant aux b√©n√©fices de la technologie pour les arts, a ajout√© que l'**IA** peut √™tre un **"outil suppl√©mentaire dans la bo√Æte √† outils des artistes"**, comme un **m√©langeur de son** ou un **pinceau pour la peinture**. Elle a √©galement soulign√© que pour certains artistes, *"la technologie rattrape leur vision, plut√¥t que leur vision ne rattrape pas la technologie."*

#### üåü **Un exemple inspirant : Dream Machine**
Pour illustrer ce potentiel, Leigh a cit√© une r√©cente commission arts et tech du Lincoln Center, **Dream Machine** de Nona Hendryx. En utilisant une combinaison d'**IA**, de **VR** et de **r√©alit√© augment√©e**, cette ≈ìuvre immerge les visiteurs, en particulier les visiteurs **BIPOC**, dans des environnements **Afrofuturistes**. Selon Leigh, Dream Machine montre comment l'art peut aider *"les personnes qui ne se voient pas dans la technologie √† commencer √† s'y voir ‚Äî en particulier les personnes noires et brunes, surtout les femmes noires et brunes."*

*"Je pense que plus il y a de personnes qui participent √† la conversation, plus nous avons de chances que ce soit une bonne conversation,"* a-t-elle ajout√©.

#### üéì **Le programme Collider Fellowship**
Les nouveaux **Collider Fellows**, s√©lectionn√©s par un processus de nomination, continueront √† explorer ce potentiel. Pendant les **neuf prochains mois**, ils b√©n√©ficieront d'un **espace de travail** au Lincoln Center et √† Onassis ONX, ainsi que d'une **bourse financi√®re** et d'un **soutien** de la part du personnel du Lincoln Center.

Leigh a pr√©cis√© que le **Collider Fellowship** fait partie d'une **plus large gamme de programmes** par lesquels le centre des arts vivants cherche √† soutenir les artistes de mani√®re *"non transactionnelle"*. Notamment, la bourse ne n√©cessite pas que les artistes participants r√©alisent un projet final ou une commission. Leigh a expliqu√© que la premi√®re promotion de Collider Fellows comprenait un artiste qui a r√©alis√© *"cinq ou six prototypes"* pendant le programme, tandis qu'un autre voulait *"prendre ce temps pour se ressourcer, lire des tonnes de livres, faire des recherches, ralentir"* ‚Äî elle a d√©clar√© que ces deux approches sont *"des mani√®res compl√®tement acceptables d'utiliser cette bourse."*

Selon Leigh, de nombreux projets issus de la premi√®re promotion sont *"toujours en germination"*, et certains pourraient potentiellement √™tre pr√©sent√©s au Lincoln Center lui-m√™me. Bien que Leigh se d√©crive comme *"redoublant d'efforts sur les exp√©riences bas√©es sur le lieu"*, en particulier celles impliquant la **VR**, la **AR** et la **r√©alit√© √©tendue**, elle a √©galement sugg√©r√© que les **Collider Fellows** pourraient aider le Lincoln Center √† repenser les fa√ßons de toucher les publics **mondiaux**.

*"Je ne pense pas que nous fermions la porte √† quoi que ce soit pour l'instant,"* a-t-elle d√©clar√©.

title: Why California‚Äôs SB 53 might provide a meaningful check on big AI companies
content:
### R√©sum√©
La Californie a approuv√© un nouveau projet de loi sur la s√©curit√© de l'IA, SB 53, qui est envoy√© au gouverneur Gavin Newsom pour signature ou veto. Ce projet de loi, plus cibl√© que le pr√©c√©dent SB 1047, vise les grandes entreprises d'IA g√©n√©rant plus de 500 millions de dollars de revenus annuels. Il impose des rapports de s√©curit√©, des d√©clarations d'incidents et des canaux de signalement pour les employ√©s. Le projet de loi a √©t√© discut√© dans le podcast Equity de TechCrunch, o√π les invit√©s soulignent son importance pour r√©guler les grandes entreprises d'IA et son impact potentiel sur l'√©cosyst√®me des startups.

### Article r√©√©crit

# üì¢ La Californie approuve un nouveau projet de loi sur la s√©curit√© de l'IA

La **chambre** du **senat** de la **Californie** a r√©cemment donn√© son **approbation finale** √† un nouveau **projet de loi** sur la **s√©curit√© de l'IA**, le **SB 53**, l'envoyant au **gouverneur Gavin Newsom** pour **signature** ou **veto**.

Si cela vous semble familier, c'est parce que **Newsom** avait **vet√©** un autre **projet de loi** sur la **s√©curit√© de l'IA**, √©galement r√©dig√© par le **s√©nateur de l'√âtat Scott Wiener**, l'ann√©e derni√®re. Mais le **SB 53** est **plus cibl√©** que le **SB 1047** pr√©c√©dent de Wiener, se concentrant sur les **grandes entreprises d'IA** g√©n√©rant plus de **500 millions de dollars** de **revenus annuels**.

J'ai eu l'occasion de discuter du **SB 53** avec mes coll√®gues **Max Zeff** et **Kirsten Korosec** lors du dernier √©pisode du **podcast phare de TechCrunch, Equity**. Max croit que le nouveau projet de loi de Wiener a **plus de chances** de devenir **loi**, en partie gr√¢ce √† ce **focus sur les grandes entreprises**, et parce qu'il a √©t√© **approuv√©** par l'entreprise d'IA **Anthropic**.

Lisez un **aper√ßu** de notre **conversation** sur la **s√©curit√© de l'IA** et la **l√©gislation au niveau de l'√âtat** ci-dessous. (J'ai √©dit√© la **transcription** pour la **longueur** et la **clart√©**, et pour nous faire para√Ætre un peu plus intelligents.)

## üí¨ Discussion sur le SB 53

**Max**: Pourquoi devriez-vous vous soucier de la **l√©gislation sur la s√©curit√© de l'IA** qui passe une **chambre** en **Californie**? Nous entrons dans une √®re o√π les **entreprises d'IA** deviennent les **entreprises les plus puissantes** au monde, et cela pourrait √™tre potentiellement l'un des **seuls freins** √† leur **pouvoir**.

Cela est beaucoup plus **cibl√©** que le **SB 1047**, qui a suscit√© beaucoup de **contestations** l'ann√©e derni√®re. Mais je pense que le **SB 53** impose toujours des **r√©gulations significatives** aux **labs d'IA**. Il les oblige √† **publier des rapports de s√©curit√©** pour leurs **mod√®les**. Si elles ont un **incident**, cela les force √† le **signaler** au **gouvernement**. Et cela donne √©galement, pour les **employ√©s** de ces **labs**, s'ils ont des **pr√©occupations**, un **canal** pour le **signaler** au **gouvernement** et ne pas faire face √† des **repr√©sailles** de la part des **entreprises**, m√™me si beaucoup d'entre elles ont **sign√© des NDAs**.

Pour moi, cela semble √™tre un **frein potentiellement significatif** au **pouvoir des entreprises technologiques**, quelque chose que nous n'avons pas vraiment eu au cours des deux derni√®res **d√©cennies**.

**Kirsten**: √Ä votre **point** sur l'importance au **niveau de l'√âtat**, il est important de penser au fait que c'est la **Californie**. Chaque **entreprise d'IA majeure** est, si ce n'est bas√©e ici, a un **impact majeur** dans cet **√âtat**. Ce n'est pas que les autres **√âtats** n'ont pas d'importance ‚Äî je ne veux pas recevoir d'emails des gens du **Colorado** ou autre ‚Äî mais cela compte que ce soit sp√©cifiquement la **Californie** parce que c'est vraiment un **hub d'activit√© d'IA**.

Ma **question** pour toi, Max, c'est qu'il semble y avoir beaucoup d'**exceptions** et d'**exemptions**. C'est plus **cibl√©**, mais est-ce plus **compliqu√©** que le [projet de loi] pr√©c√©dent?

**Max**: D'une certaine mani√®re, oui. Je dirais que la principale **exemption** de ce projet de loi est qu'il essaie vraiment de ne pas s'appliquer aux **petites startups**. Et fondamentalement, l'une des principales **controverses** autour du dernier **effort l√©gislatif** du **s√©nateur Scott Wiener**, qui repr√©sente **San Francisco**, qui a r√©dig√© ce projet de loi, beaucoup de gens ont dit qu'il pourrait nuire √† l'**√©cosyst√®me des startups**, ce √† quoi beaucoup de gens s'opposent parce que c'est une partie si **florissante** de l'**√©conomie californienne** en ce moment.

Ce projet de loi s'applique sp√©cifiquement aux **d√©veloppeurs d'IA** qui **g√©n√®rent** plus de **500 millions de dollars** de leurs **mod√®les d'IA**. Cela vise vraiment **OpenAI**, **Google DeepMind**, ces **grandes entreprises** et pas les **startups** courantes.

**Anthony**: √Ä ce que je comprends, si vous √™tes une **petite startup**, vous devez partager certaines **informations de s√©curit√©**, mais pas autant.

Il est √©galement **utile** de parler du **paysage plus large** autour de la **r√©gulation de l'IA** et du fait que l'un des **grands changements** entre l'ann√©e derni√®re et cette ann√©e est que nous avons maintenant un **nouveau pr√©sident**. L'**administration f√©d√©rale** a pris une **position** beaucoup plus **sans r√©gulation** et les **entreprises** devraient pouvoir faire ce qu'elles veulent, au point qu'elles ont m√™me inclus [du **langage**] dans les **projets de loi de financement** disant que les **√âtats** ne peuvent pas avoir leur propre **r√©gulation de l'IA**.

Je ne pense pas que cela ait pass√© pour l'instant, mais potentiellement ils pourraient essayer de le faire passer √† l'avenir. Donc cela pourrait √™tre un autre **front** dans lequel l'**administration Trump** et les **√âtats bleus** se battent.

**Equity** est le **podcast phare** de **TechCrunch**, produit par **Theresa Loconsolo**, et est diffus√© tous les **mercredi** et **vendredi**.

Abonnez-vous √† nous sur **Apple Podcasts**, **Overcast**, **Spotify**, et tous les **podcasts**. Vous pouvez √©galement suivre **Equity** sur **X** et **Threads**, √† @EquityPod.

content:
### R√©sum√©
L'√©pisode de cette semaine du podcast **Equity** de TechCrunch aborde les **derni√®res actualit√©s** dans les domaines de l'**IA**, de la **robotique** et de la **r√©gulation**. ### üéôÔ∏è **√âquit√© : Les Derni√®res Actualit√©s en IA, Robotique et R√©gulation**

Cette semaine sur **Equity**, **Anthony Ha**, **Kirsten Korosec** et **Max Zeff** **d√©cortiquent** les **plus grandes tendances** dans les domaines de l'**IA**, de la **robotique** et de la **r√©gulation**.

üéß **√âcoutez l'√©pisode complet** pour en savoir plus sur :

title: Meta Ray-Ban Display and everything else unveiled at Meta Connect 2025
content:
At Meta Connect 2025, the company‚Äôs biggest event of the year, Mark Zuckerberg unveiled three new smart glasses: the second-generation Ray-Ban Meta, the Meta Ray-Ban Display and wristband controller, and the Oakley Meta Vanguard.
Meta says it has sold 2 million of the first-generation Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses, and earlier this year, Meta unveiled its latest AI-powered smart glasses with Oakley, which were designed for athletes. Silicon Valley is leaning heavily into AI wearables, and Meta seems to be one of the companies leading the charge.
With Meta looking to regain its footing in the AI race and sell more hardware, the company had a lot at stake during Mark Zuckerberg‚Äôs Meta Connect 2025 keynote. Overall, Meta showcased some pretty impressive technology ‚Äî the Meta Neural Band, the wristband controller that comes with the Meta Ray-Ban Display, is a particular highlight.
And yet, in a twist that felt reminiscent of HBO‚Äôs ‚ÄúSilicon Valley,‚Äù Zuckerberg‚Äôs demo of the AI capabilities on the Ray-Ban Metas failed. Whoops!
While sharing a live video feed of the cooking content creator Jack Mancuso at Meta HQ, Zuckerberg asked the chef to demonstrate how his Ray-Ban Meta glasses could help him whip up a Korean-inspired steak sauce.
‚ÄúI love the setup you have here, with soy sauce and other ingredients. How can I help?‚Äù asked the chipper Meta AI voice.
Mancuso asked for a recipe for a Korean-inspired steak sauce, and the AI voice began to list the ingredients that he would need ‚Äî but Mancuso knows he needs to keep the demo succinct, so he interrupts and asks, ‚ÄúWhat do I do first?‚Äù
After a moment of silence that dragged a bit too long, Mancuso repeated, ‚ÄúWhat do I do first?‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve already combined the base ingredients, so now grate a pear to add to the sauce,‚Äù the AI said. But he had not yet combined the base ingredients, because he had not started making the recipe, hence the question of what to do first.
Mancuso asked the same question again, and the AI gave the same response. The audience laughed.
‚ÄúI think the Wi-Fi might be messed up ‚Äî back to you, Mark!‚Äù Mancuso said.
‚ÄúYou know what? It‚Äôs all good. The irony of the whole thing is that you spend years making the technology, and then the Wi-Fi of the day kind of¬†‚Ä¶ catches you,‚Äù Zuckerberg said. ‚ÄúAnyway, we‚Äôll go check out what he made later.‚Äù
The whole interaction was a bit awkward, especially since the issue did not seem to be with the Wi-Fi. But even when things are going according to plan, these presentations can feel a bit hokey¬†‚Ä¶ like the end of the keynote, when Zuckerberg and Diplo quite literally ran into the sunset together, wearing their Meta Oakley Vanguards. It had to be a busy day for Mark, so maybe he just needed an excuse to build some cardio into his schedule.
Meta unveiled the second generation of its Ray-Ban Meta glasses, which first debuted in 2023. This spruced-up model features double the battery life of its predecessor, now lasting up to eight hours of mixed use on one charge. The second-generation glasses also support ultra HD 3K video recording, which the company says is twice as sharp as the last model.
Meta‚Äôs smart glasses are also getting some new features with the release of the second-generation Ray-Ban Metas, like conversation focus, which will be available on the Ray-Ban Meta and Oakley Meta HSTN glasses.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre eating at a hot new restaurant, commuting on the train, or catching your favorite DJ‚Äôs latest set, conversation focus uses your AI glasses‚Äô open-ear speakers to amplify the voice of the person you‚Äôre talking to,‚Äù Meta said in its press release.
Conversation focus isn‚Äôt out just yet, so we can‚Äôt say for sure if it‚Äôll be any help for your next night out.
The Live AI feature ‚Äî which Meta failed to properly demo onstage ‚Äî is also on its way. But it‚Äôs so energy-intensive that you can only use it for about an hour or two.
‚ÄúAs we make battery and energy efficiency optimizations, Meta AI will transition from something you prompt with a wake word to an always-available assistant,‚Äù the company said.
The second-generation Ray-Ban Meta glasses are priced at $379.
The Meta Ray-Ban Display smart glasses are the most impressive glasses that Meta has unveiled to date, featuring a built-in display for apps, alerts, and directions on the right lens. But what sets this pair of smart glasses apart is its accompanying wristband controller, the Meta Neural Band.
This wristband lets Meta show off a bit of what it‚Äôs been spending so much time (and money) on in its Reality Labs division, which is notorious for losing billions of dollars a quarter.
Visually, the Meta Neural Band looks like a Fitbit without a screen. It‚Äôs powered by surface electromyography (sEMG), which can pick up on minute hand gestures and small movements. This is far more sophisticated than a wrist gesture on an Apple Watch. Users can write out text messages by holding their fingers together as if they were gripping a pen and ‚Äúwriting‚Äù out the text. This means that you can see a WhatsApp message come in on your right glasses lens, then answer it by ‚Äúwriting‚Äù your response.
For now, the glasses support Meta apps, but the company will have to support a wide variety of apps in the future to get the kind of adoption they‚Äôre looking for. Like¬†Apple¬†and¬†Google, Meta is betting that smart glasses could cut into the market share of the smartphone in the future ‚Äî but it will be a big challenge to force such a massive cultural shift.
The Meta Ray-Ban Display, which comes with the Meta Neural Band, will cost $799 and launches on September 30.
For the bearish among us, it seems hard to imagine wearing smart glasses and sending text messages by handwriting in the air. But the Oakley Meta Vanguard smart glasses, which are designed for athletes, offer the most coherent use case yet for this kind of technology.
Bikers, trail runners, and skiers can photograph their adventures without pulling out their phones; the glasses‚Äô open-air speakers can play music during your workout, and even link with apps like Strava and Garmin to relay your stats. Like the other new glasses, the Vanguard model is also AI-enabled.
Unlike other models of Meta smart glasses, the Oakley Meta Vanguards have just one unified front lens with a camera in the middle, rather than two lenses with cameras on either side ‚Äî it‚Äôs a design that makes more technical sense, and it‚Äôs a fashion statement that you can pull off in athletic eyewear, but not in eyeglasses (prove me wrong). The new glasses can capture video in up to 3K resolution and feature a 12-megapixel camera with a 122-degree wide-angle lens.
The glasses have an IP67 dust and water resistance rating for use during intense workouts. Meta says the wraparound design of the glasses features Oakley PRIZM Lens technology, which is designed to block out sun, wind, and dust.
Unless you‚Äôre an ultramarathon runner, these glasses will easily last throughout your workout. The glasses can stay on for nine hours, or six hours with continuous music playback. But the charging case that the glasses come with can provide an additional 36 hours of charge on the go. Meta claims that the charging case can quickly get the glasses to a 50% charge in 20 minutes.
The Oakley Meta Vanguard glasses retail for $499 and go on sale on October 21.
On the VR front, Meta did not release any new Quest headsets as part of this year‚Äôs Connect. Even though the conference and company are named after the metaverse, we learned about just a small number of updates to its VR, such as Hyperscape, which will allow developers and creators to build photorealistic spaces in virtual reality.
Meta is reportedly developing an ultralight VR headset for launch by the end of 2026, so maybe we‚Äôll see that come to fruition at the next Meta Connect event.

title: Octopus Energy spins off its Kraken utility billing and AI platform
content:
British renewable energy provider Octopus Energy said this week that it‚Äôs spinning off Kraken, its tech platform for utilities, spurred in part by $500 million in committed annual revenue from other utilities and energy providers.
An eventual Kraken IPO could be valued at $15 billion and could occur within a year, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Kraken was actually the company‚Äôs initial product, per Octopus CEO Greg Jackson. ‚ÄúWe created Octopus as the ‚Äòdemo client,‚Äô‚Äù he told the Journal earlier this year. That demo client has since grown to provide power to more than 7.7 million households in the U.K. and another 2.8 million elsewhere.
The spinoff would help Kraken minimize conflicts of interest as it signs deals with utilities and power providers that aren‚Äôt Octopus, the company said. Octopus originally set the spinoff in motion last year.
Octopus was founded in 2015, and within a decade became the U.K.‚Äôs largest energy provider, overtaking British Gas, which was founded more than 200 years ago.
Part of that growth has stemmed from creative marketing and customer-acquisition strategies.
One, called Zero Bills, allowed homeowners to eliminate their energy bills for a decade if they bought properties that were entirely electrified. Another, a tariff it calls Agile, encourages customers to shift their electricity use to times when there‚Äôs a surplus on the grid. In some cases, consumers can run loads of laundry for free.
As Octopus gathered data from those projects, it used AI models built into Kraken to sift through it to determine how increasing amounts of renewable energy can work on the grid.
For utilities and power providers, Kraken allows them to call on power sources when needed, including renewables, solar, and so-called distributed energy resources, which include EV chargers, smart thermostats, and home batteries. It has also built a customer management system that covers everything from billing, meter management, and customer relations.

title: How developers are using Apple‚Äôs local AI models with iOS 26
content:
Earlier this year, Apple introduced its Foundation Models framework during WWDC 2025, which allows developers to use the company‚Äôs local AI models to power features in their applications.
The company touted that with this framework, developers gain access to AI models without worrying about any inference cost. Plus, these local models have capabilities such as guided generation and tool calling built in.
As iOS 26 is rolling out to all users, developers have been updating their apps to include features powered by Apple‚Äôs local AI models. Apple‚Äôs models are small compared with leading models from OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, or Meta. That is why local-only features largely improve quality of life with these apps rather than introducing major changes to the app‚Äôs workflow.
Below are some of the first apps to tap into Apple‚Äôs AI framework.
The Lil Artist app offers various interactive experiences to help kids learn different skills like creativity, math, and music. Developer Arima Jain shipped an AI story creator with the iOS 26 update. This allows users to select a character and a theme, with the app generating a story using AI. The developer said that the text generation in the story is powered by the local model.
The developer of the Daylish app is working on a prototype for automatically suggesting emojis for timeline events based on the title for the daily planner app.
Finance tracking app MoneyCoach has two neat features powered by local models. First, the app shows insights about your spending, such as whether you spent more than average on groceries for that particular week. The other feature automatically suggests categories and subcategories for a spending item for quick entries.
The word learning app LookUp has added two new modes using Apple‚Äôs AI models. There is a new learning mode, which leverages a local model to create examples corresponding to a word. Plus, the example asks users to explain the usage of the word in a sentence.
The developer is also using on-device models to generate a map view of a word‚Äôs origin.
Just like a few other apps, the Tasks app implemented a feature to suggest tags for an entry using local models automatically. It‚Äôs also using these models to detect a recurring task and schedule it accordingly. And the app lets users speak a few things and use the local model to break them down into various tasks without using the internet.
Automattic-owned journaling app Day One is using Apple‚Äôs models to get highlights and suggest titles for your entry. The team has also implemented a feature to generate prompts that nudge you to dive deeper and write more based on what you have already written.
Recipe app Crouton is using Apple Intelligence to suggest tags for a recipe and assign names to timers. It also uses AI to break down a block of text into easy-to-follow steps for cooking.
Digital signing app SignEasy is using Apple‚Äôs local models to extract key insights from a contract and give users a summary of the document they are signing.
We will continue updating this list as we discover more apps using Apple‚Äôs local models.

title: OpenAI‚Äôs research on AI models deliberately lying is wild
content:
Every now and then, researchers at the biggest tech companies drop a bombshell. There was the time Google said its latest quantum chip indicated multiple universes exist. Or when Anthropic gave its AI agent Claudius a snack¬†vending machine to run and it went amok, calling security on people and insisting it was human.
This week, it was OpenAI‚Äôs turn to raise our collective eyebrows.
OpenAI released on Monday some research that explained how it‚Äôs stopping AI models from ‚Äúscheming.‚Äù It‚Äôs a  practice in which an ‚ÄúAI behaves one way on the surface while hiding its true goals,‚Äù OpenAI defined in its tweet about the research.
In the¬†paper, conducted with Apollo Research, researchers went a bit further, likening AI scheming to a human stock broker breaking the law to make as much money as possible. The researchers, however, argued that most AI ‚Äúscheming‚Äù wasn‚Äôt that harmful. ‚ÄúThe most common failures involve simple forms of deception ‚Äî for instance, pretending to have completed a task without actually doing so,‚Äù they wrote.
The paper was mostly published to show that ‚Äúdeliberative alignment‚Å†‚Äù¬†‚Äî the anti-scheming technique they were testing ‚Äî worked well.
But¬†it also explained that AI developers haven‚Äôt figured out a way to train their models not to scheme. That‚Äôs because such training could actually teach the model how to scheme even better to avoid being detected.
‚ÄúA major failure mode of attempting to ‚Äòtrain out‚Äô scheming is simply teaching the model to scheme more carefully and covertly,‚Äù the researchers wrote.
Perhaps the most astonishing part is that, if a model understands that it‚Äôs¬†being tested, it can pretend it‚Äôs not scheming just to pass the test, even if it is still scheming. ‚ÄúModels often become more aware that they are being evaluated. This situational awareness can itself reduce scheming, independent of genuine alignment,‚Äù the researchers wrote.
It‚Äôs not news that AI models will lie. By now most of us have experienced AI hallucinations, or the model confidently giving an answer to a prompt that simply isn‚Äôt true. But hallucinations are basically presenting guesswork with confidence, as OpenAI research released earlier this month documented.
Scheming is something else. It‚Äôs deliberate.
Even this revelation ‚Äî that a model will deliberately mislead humans ‚Äî isn‚Äôt new.¬†Apollo Research first published a paper in December documenting how five models schemed when they were given instructions to achieve a goal¬†‚Äúat all costs.‚Äù
The news here is actually good news: The researchers saw significant reductions in scheming by using ‚Äúdeliberative alignment‚Å†.‚Äù That technique involves teaching the model an ‚Äúanti-scheming specification‚Äù and then making the model go review it before acting. It‚Äôs a bit like making little kids repeat the rules¬†before allowing them to play.
OpenAI researchers insist that the lying they‚Äôve caught with their own models, or even with ChatGPT, isn‚Äôt that serious. As OpenAI‚Äôs co-founder Wojciech Zaremba told TechCrunch‚Äôs Maxwell Zeff about this research: ‚ÄúThis work has been done in the simulated environments, and we think it represents future use cases. However,¬†today, we haven‚Äôt seen this kind of consequential scheming in our production traffic. Nonetheless, it is well known that there are forms of deception in ChatGPT. You might ask it to implement some website, and it might tell you, ‚ÄòYes, I did a great job.‚Äô And that‚Äôs just the lie. There are some petty forms of deception that we still need to address.‚Äù
The fact that AI models from multiple players intentionally deceive humans is, perhaps, understandable. They were built by humans, to mimic humans, and (synthetic data aside) for the most part trained on data produced by humans.
While we‚Äôve all experienced the frustration of poorly performing technology (thinking of you, home printers of yesteryear), when was the last time your not-AI software deliberately lied to you? Has your inbox ever fabricated¬†emails on its own? Has your CMS logged new prospects that didn‚Äôt exist to pad its numbers? Has your fintech app made up its own bank transactions?
It‚Äôs worth pondering this as the corporate world barrels toward an AI future where companies believe agents can be treated like independent employees. The researchers of this paper have the same warning.
‚ÄúAs AIs are assigned more complex tasks with real-world consequences and begin pursuing more ambiguous, long-term goals, we expect that the potential for harmful scheming will grow ‚Äî so our safeguards and our ability to rigorously test must grow correspondingly,‚Äù they wrote.
¬© 2025 TechCrunch Media LLC.

title: Huawei¬†announces new AI infrastructure as Nvidia gets locked out of China
content:
Tech giant¬†Huawei¬†unveiled new¬†AI¬†infrastructure¬†meant to help¬†boost¬†compute¬†power¬†and allow the company to better compete with rival chipmaker Nvidia.
At a keynote at its Huawei Connect conference¬†on Thursday, Shenzhen, China-based¬†Huawei announced¬†new¬†SuperPoD¬†Interconnect¬†technology that can link¬†together up to 15,000¬†graphics cards, including Huawei‚Äôs Ascend AI chips, to increase compute power.
This¬†tech¬†seems to be¬†a competitor for Nvidia‚Äôs¬†NVLink¬†infrastructure,¬†which¬†facilitates¬†high-speed communication between¬†AI¬†chips.
Technology¬†like this¬†is critical for Huawei to better compete with¬†semiconductors like¬†Nvidia‚Äôs. While Huawei‚Äôs AI chips are less¬†powerful than Nvidia‚Äôs,¬†being able to cluster them¬†together¬†will give its users¬†access to¬†more¬†compute¬†power,¬†which is needed for training and scaling AI¬†systems.
This news also comes just a day after¬†China banned domestic tech companies¬†from buying Nvidia‚Äôs hardware, including¬†Nvidia‚Äôs¬†RTX Pro 600D servers specifically designed for the market in China.
TechCrunch¬†reached out to Huawei for more information.
